We have more newsletters Show Me No thanks, close See our Privacy Notice At Old Trafford, Tom Lawrence is best remembered as the answer to a pub quiz teaser. Name the then Manchester United youngster who made way for Ryan Giggs as the Premier League legend stepped off the bench to make his last ever appearance for the Red Devils? Almost 10 years have passed since the Welshman claimed his little place in United history, being replaced by his fellow countryman 70 minutes into his sole senior appearance in a red shirt. Now he’s wearing blue at Ibrox but there’s still questions to be addressed - chiefly, when can the Rangers support expect to see him back in action on a consistent basis. It’s one Lawrence has had to face before and, frankly, he’s sick of it. But not as sick of the repeated injury set-backs that have blighted his 18-months in Glasgow. Last season was written off after just a month after signing from Derby. Read More Related Articles Transfer news LIVE as Celtic and Rangers plus Aberdeen, Hearts and Hibs eye signings Read More Related Articles Inside the refs SFA summit as Rangers row hits boiling point with Willie Collum crisis throwing up 'investment' demands And he’s now on to comeback No3 having endured two more stints on the sidelines this term. But having rejoined Philippe Clement’s Gers in Spain for this week’s training camp, Lawrence - who turned 30 this week - hopes this is the last time he’ll have to face a quizzing on his readiness to perform. “It’s all good, he said. “It was good to get out to Spain and get some training done. I’m just looking forward now. “I’m back training with the team, I’m injury free at the minute. I’m sick of talking about it to be honest. I'm sick of being injured, I just want to get fit and hopefully I can do that. “It was a massive couple months when the gaffer first arrived. I played my part when I was fit so I know what I need to do and I know what to expect.” Lawrence had barely started primary school when he joined United. His footballing education at Old Trafford took place at a time when the Class of 92 were on the books. He himself graduated into the first-team in May 2014 as he was given his debut by Giggs in a win over Hull. Trivia geeks will remember that Giggs was acting as player-manager at the time he chose to take off the young Lawrence and throw himself on for his 963rd and final Man United run-out. But the fact the 13-time Premier League winner was even required to double up in a caretaker capacity was an early sign of the troubles that have plagued the club ever since. The United Way has lost its bearings since the departure of Sir Alex Ferguson but for Lawrence, the strict lessons he learned from some of the game’s biggest names have stuck with him - and are the ones he’s now trying to pass on to the young students at Ibrox. Ryan Giggs replaces Tom Lawrence for his final man Utd appearance Looking back on his first-team debut, Lawrence said: “I started the game and Ryan came on for me. “It was his last ever game for Manchester United as he was player/manager at the time. I played 70 minutes and then he came on. “He was a big hero growing up, there were a few of them. But he gave me my Manchester United debut so I’ll be forever grateful. “I was at United from the age of seven until I was 20. You looked up to those who were in the first team at the time, the likes of Giggs and Paul Scholes. “Coaching-wise, Paul McGuinness and Warren Joyce helped me massively. I’m really thankful to them all. “There were role models everywhere. It was just all about standards, it makes you have those standards from such a young age. “That’s what I try to do at Rangers, I try to bring standards the best I can. Sir Alex Ferguson was one for big standards and you couldn’t mess up. “That grounding never leaves you. When you grow up hearing that you just get used to doing the same high level standard stuff every day. It’s instilled in you. “It’s a lot different now but when the younger players do come up to train with us, you try and give them as much confidence as you can.” Fergie Time was over by the time Lawrence made it to the first team under Giggs but the iconic Scot still had an influence over his career. He gave me my first professional contract,” he revealed. “I didn’t actually play under him in the first team because he left the season before. “But he knew everything about everyone. He’d pull you in for a chat in his office and he’d know everything. Tom Lawrence “He was quite an insight. You didn’t want to be uneasy around him because that’s not how he wants you to be. You just knew if you put a foot wrong he’d find out.” Lawrence now hopes he can help Rangers take a step in the right direction as Clement’s team gears up for a huge second half to the season. The title race will still be very much alive if the Ibrox side can win their two games in hand to cut Celtic’s lead back to two points, while the Viaplay Cup winners will be eyeing further prizes in the Europa League and Scottish Cup. “There’s a lot of excitement ahead of the second half of the season,” he said. “I can’t wait to get back out on that pitch playing, I think it will be very special. “We’ve become a lot closer as a squad. We had a lot of new faces in the summer. It always takes a bit of time but we’ve got a strong team bond now and hopefully that shows in the second half of the season.” Lawrence wasn’t quite ready to take part in the team’s La Manga kick-about with Hertha Berlin on Saturday but he’s hoping to play a part in tonight’s friendly clash with Copenhagen. He added: “These games are crucial after a break. “I’ve not played for five weeks so I just want to play as many games as I can to get my fitness back to that peak level.” Lawrence was speaking to promote Rangers’ friendly with Copenhagen at Ibrox on Tuesday. newsArray.content: Cherchant à mettre la main sur de nouvelles pépites, le PSG scruterait le marché en Amérique du Sud. Le club de la capitale avait notamment coché le nom de Claudio Echeverri sur sa liste. Mais le crack de River Plate devrait finalement rejoindre Manchester City. Le PSG pourrait d'ailleurs s'en mordre les doigts au vu du potentiel du milieu offensif de 18 ans. À la recherche de nouvelles pépites, le PSG scrute attentivement le marché en Amérique du Sud. Après Lucas Beraldo , le club de la capitale aurait prévu de mettre la main sur Gabriel Moscardo . Mais Luis Campos gardait également un œil en Argentine. Le conseiller football parisien avait notamment coché le nom de Claudio Echeverri sur sa liste. Mercato - PSG : Il l’annonce, Mbappé va recaler Al-Khelaïfi ! https://t.co/53YsvKD1Ae pic.twitter.com/v78JtN7TtR Le milieu offensif de 18 ans a fait sensation avec River Plate . Le crack argentin avait plusieurs prétendants à ses pieds, dont le PSG il y a quelques semaines. Mais finalement, Claudio Echeverri va rejoindre Manchester City . La pépite de River Plate aurait donné son feu vert à l’équipe de Pep Guardiola . Le PSG aurait ainsi raté un véritable phénomène. « C'est un prodige, un croisement entre Maradona et Messi. C'est un joueur totalement différent des autres. Quand je l'ai vu bouger, je me suis excité dès le premier contrôle orienté, parce que je savais que j'avais trouvé un autre type de footballeur. Sans aucun doute, c'est un enfant prodige » a expliqué Daniel Brizuela pour Página 12 . Le PSG pourrait bien avoir des regrets. Claudio Echeverri n'est d'ailleurs pas le premier à avoir échappé au club de la capitale. Il y a quelques mois, la direction parisienne convoitait Endrick . Le crack de Palmeiras rejoindra cependant le Real Madrid l'été prochain. Vitor Roque était également sur la liste du PSG . Mais la pépite de l' Athletico Paranaense a signé au FC Barcelone cet hiver. Claudio Echeverri est seulement venu s'ajouter à cette longue liste.
